inception1_start.speaker: professor
inception1_start.dialogue: Time 5:00 AM! Who could have come here at this early hour... Who are you?

inception1_02.dialogue: I need Robert Langdon. This is FBI Director J. Edgar Hoover speaking.
inception1_02.speaker: director

inception1_03.dialogue: Who?! Are you sure you need me?!
inception1_03.speaker: professor

inception1_05.dialogue: Do you know what time it is?!
inception1_05.speaker: professor

inception1_06.dialogue: Please excuse me, but this matter is urgent.
inception1_06.speaker: director

inception1_08.dialogue: Professor Langdon, this is a matter of life and death! I ask you to help your country! The life of the entire planet depends on your help!
inception1_08.speaker: director

inception1_09.dialogue: You intrigue me. What is it about my humble person that has so interested the FBI that Director Hoover himself came to see me personally?
inception1_09.speaker: professor

inception1_10.dialogue: I'm not joking. Listen carefully! A group of hackers led by Kevin Mitnick has created a dangerous virus.
inception1_10.speaker: director

inception1_11.dialogue: It can disrupt the operation of the World Wide Web. It is distributed through a regular message.

inception1_12.dialogue: Last night, information security specialist Sarah Parker's computer was hacked, files were stolen, and this virus was released onto the network.

inception1_13.dialogue: We have less than 20 hours left to create an antivirus.

inception1_14.dialogue: I understand you, Mr. Hoover, but I am not very familiar with the Prolog language...
inception1_14.speaker: professor

inception1_15.dialogue: You are the world's best information security specialist. You are the fastest to learn new programming languages. The life of the entire planet is at stake!
inception1_15.speaker: director

inception1_16.dialogue: Okay, I'll try to figure it out!
inception1_16.speaker: professor

inception1_17.dialogue: Last night, Sarah Parker was kidnapped from her home. Her whereabouts are still unknown
inception1_17.speaker: director

inception1_18.dialogue: But we have located the very computer that we need to inject the antivirus into.
inception1_18.speaker: director

inception1_19.dialogue: I take it that we are going there now?
inception1_19.speaker: professor

inception1_20.dialogue: Yes. The car is waiting for us downstairs. But be careful in this abandoned mansion there are life-threatening traps everywhere.
inception1_20.speaker: director

inception1_21.dialogue: To secure them, you must enter the correct code. I believe in you, Professor Langdon! Call me anytime! Good luck!
inception1_21.speaker: director

inception2_start.speaker: professor
inception2_start.dialogue: What a thicket here... everything has grown over. Oh, the castle. What is encrypted here?

inception2_01.dialogue: Stop! Who goes there?! Stop, living creature! You are wandering in these places in vain! Such creatures are forbidden to walk here!
inception2_01.speaker: robot

inception2_02.dialogue: Hello! My name is Professor Robert Langdon! What is your name?
inception2_02.speaker: professor

inception2_03.dialogue: Ah, you are that professor who is the best specialist in information security.
inception2_03.speaker: robot

inception2_04.dialogue: At first I thought that the looters had come again, I thought they would try to break down the door again.

inception2_05.dialogue: After all, no one can enter the correct code. And I am a third-generation robot, model R3, I must not let anyone alive in here.
inception2_05.speaker: robot

inception2_06.dialogue: After all, no one knows about the death traps. Why did you come here, Professor Langdon?
inception2_06.speaker: robot

inception2_07.dialogue: You are a robot model R3, a robot assistant to humans. Your job is to listen and help any person. Right?
inception2_07.speaker: professor

inception2_08.dialogue: Kevin Mitnick has created a virus that can disrupt the operation of the world wide web, he has already launched it.
inception2_08.speaker: professor

inception2_09.dialogue: Less than 18 hours left to create an antivirus in Prolog. Will you help me learn it?
inception2_09.speaker: professor

inception2_10.dialogue: Yes, I have such a function programmed.
inception2_10.speaker: robot

inception2_11.dialogue: But to study this language, you need to move away from the usual forms of programming and try to delve into the logic of the language itself.

inception2_12.dialogue: Believe me, this is a pretty beautiful and logical programming language. Very soon you will appreciate all its beauty and possibilities.

inception2_13.dialogue: I have no doubt about it. Can we move on to the lesson already?
inception2_13.speaker: professor

inception2_14.dialogue: Let's get started! I have a tablet, with its help you can learn more about the Prolog language. It can help you pass the assignments.
inception2_14.speaker: robot

inception2_15.dialogue: A very useful thing. Give it to me... Let's see what we have here...
inception2_15.speaker: professor

inception2_16.dialogue: The theoretical basis of Prolog is a branch of symbolic logic called the predicate calculus.

inception2_17.dialogue: A predicate is a logical function that expresses some relation between its arguments

inception2_18.dialogue: A Prolog program contains a description of a problem, which is a set of logical statements of the form facts.

inception2_19.dialogue: Based on the given rules and facts, Prolog makes inferences.

inception2_20.dialogue: Different symbols have their own specific meanings, which are used to denote facts, variables, predicates, and other elements of syntax.
inception2_20.speaker: professor

inception2_21.dialogue:
The period `.` is used to end a sentence. This is a required character, indicating that the record is complete.
`human(professor).`
inception2_21.speaker: professor

inception2_22.dialogue: The underscore (`_`) is used to denote an anonymous variable. Such a variable can have any value, but its value is not used.
inception2_22.speaker: professor

inception2_23.dialogue: The dash (`-`) is used as part of various constructions. In rules to denote the separator between the condition and the conclusion (`:-`).
inception2_23.speaker: professor

inception2_24.dialogue: A variable name starts with a capital letter or an underscore. Variables store values ​​during calculations.
inception2_24.speaker: professor

inception2_25.dialogue: I learned so much useful information for myself, well, let's try to complete the task...
inception2_25.speaker: professor

inception2_27.dialogue: ...Okay. I see it's time to continue our journey... and our learning.

inception2_failTask0_02.dialogue: Please be careful. And watch your health. You seem to be getting nervous...

inception2_failTask0_03.dialogue: Focus, Professor! This is your last attempt...

inception3_start.speaker: professor
inception3_start.dialogue: We successfully completed the first task! I didn't expect it to work out so quickly!

inception3_01.dialogue: Yes, you are very smart and quick-witted, professor. I'm so happy for you!
inception3_01.speaker: robot

inception3_03.dialogue: Professor Langdon, this is FBI Director J. Edgar Hoover. I have some breaking news for you!
inception3_03.speaker: director

inception3_05.dialogue: We've tracked down Kevin Mitnick. He's somewhere in the house. Be careful, professor! He might have a weapon!
inception3_05.speaker: director

inception3_06.dialogue: I understand, I have a weapon too, but I still don't know how to shoot. Let's hope we won't need it.
inception3_06.speaker: professor

inception3_07.dialogue: Take care of yourself, professor, you have an important mission! Goodbye!
inception3_07.speaker: director

inception3_08.dialogue: It's so dark and gloomy in here! But we can't wait. If Mitnick is somewhere in the house, I really don't want to meet him.
inception3_08.speaker: professor

inception3_09.dialogue: Let the FBI agents deal with him themselves. Let's go go up!
inception3_09.speaker: professor

inception3_10.dialogue: Be careful as you go up, professor! There are traps hidden in some of the steps of the ladder. These are the next tasks.
inception3_10.speaker: robot

inception3_11.dialogue: The concept of a variable in logic programming differs from that accepted in traditional programming languages.
inception3_11.speaker: professor

inception3_12.dialogue: In a program, a variable is denoted by a sequence of characters that begins with a capital letter.
inception3_12.speaker: professor

inception3_13.dialogue: A variable denotes an undefined (but single) object and is used to denote an object that cannot be referenced by name.
inception3_13.speaker: professor

inception3_14.dialogue: A variable can be free, bound, and anonymous. A free variable is a variable whose value is not known.
inception3_14.speaker: professor

inception3_15.dialogue: A bound variable is a variable that has been given a value by inference.
inception3_15.speaker: professor

inception3_16.dialogue: An anonymous variable is a variable used to ignore a value that is not needed.
inception3_16.speaker: professor

inception3_17.dialogue: An anonymous variable can be used instead of any other variable. It corresponds to something.
inception3_17.speaker: professor

inception3_18.dialogue: In the program, such a variable is denoted by the underscore (`_`).
inception3_18.speaker: professor

inception3_19.dialogue: How interesting! Well, let's try to solve the task.
inception3_19.speaker: professor

inception3_failTask1_02.dialogue: Please be careful. And watch your health. It seems you are starting to get nervous...

inception3_21.dialogue: Okay, Professor. Now we can go up.

inception4_start.speaker: professor
inception4_start.dialogue: Great, we're doing great! Let's move on quickly! Oops, we've run into a locked door again. You need to enter a code here too...

inception4_01.dialogue: You've already completed 2 tasks! Don't lose heart, professor!
inception4_01.speaker: robot

inception4_02.dialogue: Did you know that artificial intelligence is capable of killing humanity?
inception4_02.speaker: professor

inception4_03.dialogue: Artificial intelligence was created to make human life better.
inception4_03.speaker: robot

inception4_04.dialogue: Everything requires human control. Until AI is completely under our control, we expose ourselves to great danger.
inception4_04.speaker: professor

inception4_05.dialogue: The biggest danger we have right now is not being able to complete all the tasks in 6 hours.
inception4_05.speaker: robot

inception4_06.dialogue: That's where my friend, you're absolutely right! Let's get down to business!
inception4_06.speaker: professor

inception4_07.dialogue: Prologue is a declarative language. A fact is a statement that is always true without any condition.
inception4_07.speaker: professor

inception4_08.dialogue: A rule is a statement whose truth is proved depending on a given condition.
inception4_08.speaker: professor

inception4_09.dialogue: A rule succeeds only if the goals specified in the rule body are achievable, otherwise the rule fails.
inception4_09.speaker: professor

inception4_10.dialogue: A goal is a statement that is asked as a question about facts and rules.
inception4_10.speaker: professor

inception4_11.dialogue: Query example: given facts `likes(professor, book).`, `likes(vicky, dad).`
inception4_11.speaker: professor

inception4_12.dialogue: Let's write the query: `?- likes(X, book).`, where the value for X is such that the rule or fact matches. Answer: `X = professor`
inception4_12.speaker: professor

inception4_13.dialogue: I've discovered so much new information for myself, now I'll move on to the task...
inception4_13.speaker: professor

inception4_failTask2_02.dialogue: Please be careful. And watch your health. You seem to be getting nervous...

inception4_failTask2_03.dialogue: Focus, Professor! This is your last attempt...

inception4_15.dialogue: ...Okay. I see, it's time to continue our journey... and our learning.

elaboration2_start.speaker: professor
elaboration2_start.dialogue: I couldn't even imagine that this scary house could have such a cozy office. As if someone had been here recently and left papers on the table...

elaboration2_01.dialogue: A very nice and cute room.
elaboration2_01.speaker: robot

elaboration2_02.dialogue: There is no computer here, so we'll have to keep looking... Do you see this? The wall moves aside...
elaboration2_02.speaker: professor

elaboration2_03.dialogue: Wow! Maybe Mitnick decided to return to his office?
elaboration2_03.speaker: robot

elaboration2_04.dialogue: I'll hide under the table so no one sees me. Ouch, oh, oh...
elaboration2_04.speaker: professor

elaboration2_05.dialogue: Here's another hidden trap. I accidentally touched some mechanism and found myself trapped. Metal bars dropped down from all sides of the table.

elaboration2_06.dialogue: Do you hear sounds? That's my daughter's voice...

elaboration2_07.dialogue: Wow! Just look at it! It's like you've stepped into another world from the dungeon. How cozy!
elaboration2_07.speaker: vicky

elaboration2_08.dialogue: Dad?! What are you doing here?!
elaboration2_08.speaker: vicky

elaboration2_09.dialogue: I wanted to ask you the same question! I expected to see anyone here but you! How did you end up here?!
elaboration2_09.speaker: professor

elaboration2_10.dialogue: I just know that you can't cope without me! And you would never call me yourself!
elaboration2_10.speaker: vicky

elaboration2_11.dialogue: Do you even realize that it's not safe here?! How did you manage to get in here?
elaboration2_11.speaker: professor

elaboration2_12.dialogue: Sleight of hand and no trickery!
elaboration2_12.speaker: vicky

elaboration2_13.dialogue: Did you hack the FBI website again?!
elaboration2_13.speaker: professor

elaboration2_14.dialogue: Oh, Dad, stop swearing! Just admit that you were waiting for me and are very happy that I appeared! You're trapped under the table, how were you even going to get out of here without me?
elaboration2_14.speaker: vicky

elaboration2_15.dialogue: All you have to do is complete the next task and enter the code.
elaboration2_15.speaker: professor

elaboration2_16.dialogue: With me, you'll get there faster! Just admit it!
elaboration2_16.speaker: vicky

elaboration2_17.dialogue: I apologize for interrupting your conversation, but there is little time left. Plus, anyone can come in here!
elaboration2_17.speaker: robot

elaboration2_18.dialogue: Yes, you are right, we need to free father and go look for the computer already!
elaboration2_18.speaker: vicky

elaboration2_19.dialogue: But first, let me read the theory...
elaboration2_19.speaker: vicky

elaboration2_20.dialogue: Lists are an important structure in Prolog. They allow you to store arbitrary amounts of data.

elaboration2_21.dialogue: A linked list is a data structure made up of nodes. A node contains data and a link (pointer, connection) to one or two neighboring nodes.

elaboration2_22.dialogue: Lists in Prolog are singly linked, each node contains only one link. There are built-in functions for working with lists:

elaboration2_23.dialogue: `sum_list(List, Sum)` — calculates the sum of the elements of a list.

elaboration2_24.dialogue: `member(Elem, List)` — searches for a value in a list. Successful if the element is found.

elaboration2_25.dialogue: `reverse(List, ReverseList)` — function to reverse a list.

elaboration2_26.dialogue: `length(List, Length)` — calculates the length of a list.
elaboration2_26.speaker: vicky

elaboration2_27.dialogue: `append(List1, List2, List1AndList2)` — function to merge two lists.
elaboration2_27.speaker: vicky

elaboration2_28.dialogue: `delete(InputList, Elem, ResultList)` is a function for deleting all elements with a given value from a list.
elaboration2_28.speaker: vicky

elaboration2_29.dialogue: I didn't even know such functions existed... let's try to apply them now.
elaboration2_29.speaker: vicky

elaboration3_01.dialogue: Let me help you get out, professor?
elaboration3_01.speaker: robot

elaboration3_02.dialogue: I can still crawl out from under the table myself. Thank you! Quiet! Do you hear these sounds?
elaboration3_02.speaker: professor

elaboration3_05.dialogue: It sounds like some kind of mooing. The sounds are coming from that far corner of the room...
elaboration3_05.speaker: professor

elaboration3_06.dialogue: Let's go see who's there! We need to shine a flashlight...
elaboration3_06.speaker: vicky

elaboration3_06_1.dialogue: Yes, it's the kidnapped information security specialist Sarah Parker! I'll help you now!

elaboration3_07.dialogue: Are you Professor Langdon?! My name is Sarah Parker! Kevin Mitnick kidnapped me from my own home last night! He's gone crazy and he must be stopped immediately!
elaboration3_07.speaker: sarah

elaboration3_08.dialogue: I thought that the director would turn to you for help !
elaboration3_08.speaker: sarah

elaboration3_09.dialogue: Nice to meet you miss, I confess I didn't expect to see you here !
elaboration3_09.speaker: professor

elaboration3_10.dialogue: Help me get free, please! I know where the main computer is ! We need to hurry, there is little time left!
elaboration3_10.speaker: sarah

elaboration3_11.dialogue: Let me introduce you to my daughter Vicky. We will now complete the task together with her and enter the correct code to free you, miss.
elaboration3_11.speaker: professor

elaboration3_12.dialogue: I have heard about you, miss, no less than about your outstanding father. I believe that you will succeed!
elaboration3_12.speaker: sarah

elaboration3_13.dialogue: Then let's get started! Let's read the theory ...
elaboration3_13.speaker: professor

elaboration3_14.dialogue: Let's consider an example where facts are linked by a conditional relationship with other already known facts, in this case they can be called rules:

elaboration3_15.dialogue:
`likes(professor, X) :- likes(vicky, X).`
`% Professor likes everything that Vicky likes.`

elaboration3_16.dialogue:
`likes(professor, X)` is the rule header.
`likes(vicky, X)` is the rule body. or its tail target.

elaboration3_17.dialogue: For a rule to be true, its tail targets must be true.

elaboration3_18.dialogue: The `:-` symbol has the meaning of "if". It separates the two parts of a rule: the header and the body. You can use `if` instead.

elaboration3_19.dialogue: I understand everything, let's move on to the task...

elaboration3_failTask4_02.dialogue: Please be careful. And watch your health. Looks like you're getting nervous...

elaboration3_21.dialogue: Okay... Looks like the trap has been deactivated.

elaboration4_start.speaker: sarah
elaboration4_start.dialogue: Thank you for helping to free me! Now we can't delay, time is short, let's go further!

elaboration4_01.dialogue: Agreed, send. Look! What a machine!
elaboration4_01.speaker: vicky

elaboration4_02.dialogue: This is, of course, not a supercomputer, but still quite powerful...
elaboration4_02.speaker: professor

elaboration4_03.dialogue: Look, the computer is on and downloading some files. Let's see what's in there?
elaboration4_03.speaker: sarah

elaboration4_04.dialogue: There's a whole list of encrypted personal data of US Mint employees. As far as I know, only 10 of them have access to the Fort Knox vault.
elaboration4_04.speaker: professor

elaboration4_05.dialogue: To get inside the vault, each of them must enter their part of the code and then 'sim-sim' will open its doors.
elaboration4_05.speaker: professor

elaboration4_06.dialogue: In the entire history of Fort Knox, outsiders have only entered it three times.
elaboration4_06.speaker: professor

elaboration4_07.dialogue: Who was given such an honor and why were they able to get there?
elaboration4_07.speaker: vicky

elaboration4_08.dialogue: The first of those who got there was the American President Roosevelt in 1943. And the second time the reserves were checked only 31 years later.
elaboration4_08.speaker: professor

elaboration4_09.dialogue: And the third inspection happened in 2018, as rumors began to circulate that there was no gold in the vault. But it turned out to be just a rumor, all the gold was there.
elaboration4_09.speaker: professor

elaboration4_10.dialogue: I wonder if the mint employees are also in on Mitnik or if he wants to use them in the dark?
elaboration4_10.speaker: sarah

elaboration4_11.dialogue: We'll definitely figure this out later, but now we need to stop the virus and enter the code before anyone interferes with us.
elaboration4_11.speaker: vicky

elaboration4_12.dialogue: Yes, let's get started. I'm ready.
elaboration4_12.speaker: robot

elaboration4_13.dialogue: When during goal resolution Prologue encounters not a fact but a rule, it first unifies the rule's title.
elaboration4_13.speaker: professor

elaboration4_14.dialogue: i.e. compares bound variables and assigns values to free variables.
elaboration4_14.speaker: professor

elaboration4_15.dialogue: If the arguments are successfully unified, the argument values from the header are substituted into the first predicate in the rule body...
elaboration4_15.speaker: professor

elaboration4_16.dialogue: and sets this predicate as a subgoal, which it begins to unify with the knowledge base.
elaboration4_16.speaker: professor

elaboration4_17.dialogue: If unification of this condition predicate fails, then fallback to the previous rule condition is performed.
elaboration4_17.speaker: professor

elaboration4_18.dialogue: This fallback only occurs if this previous predicate is ambiguous. Let's explain this with an example.
elaboration4_18.speaker: professor

elaboration4_19.dialogue:
`parent (Who, Vicky)`
The `Who` variable in the goal predicate is a free variable.
elaboration4_19.speaker: professor

elaboration4_20.dialogue: We could have used `X` instead of `Who`, and they would have been different variables that would have been unified in the same way.
elaboration4_20.speaker: professor

elaboration4_21.dialogue: Interesting, interesting... let's move on to the task.
elaboration4_21.speaker: professor

elaboration4_23.dialogue: Okay. Now it's time to enter the code...

0A_1.speaker: professor
0A_1.dialogue: Oh no, 7 seconds left, what to do?..

0A_2.dialogue: Wait, where did Vicky go... I just hope she has a plan.

1A_start.dialogue: Victory! We managed to interrupt the download of the virus itself.

1A_1.dialogue: But what if Mitnick has a copy of the virus? We need to download an antivirus so that the network systems can intercept and destroy it.

2A_start.speaker: anonymous
2A_start.dialogue: ...2 ...1 ...0. The virus has been successfully uploaded and launched on the server...

2A_1.speaker: vicky
2A_1.dialogue: No!.. Is there really nothing we can do?

2A_2.speaker: professor
2A_2.dialogue: I'm afraid so... In the next few minutes, the virus will wreak havoc across the entire World Wide Web.

2A_3.dialogue: That's what happened. Just an hour later, reports of disasters began to come in -- in space, in the air, in data centers.

2A_4.dialogue: If only we could start over...

3A_start.speaker: professor
3A_start.dialogue: Uh... We didn't have time to stop the virus from downloading.

3A_1.dialogue: Luckily, Vicky managed to download and deploy the antivirus we wrote...

3A_3.dialogue: My virus uses advanced machine learning algorithms. Over time, he will be able to adapt and bypass any defense system!
3A_3.speaker: mitnik

3A_4.dialogue: And while he is free... I will rule the world!

4A_start.speaker: anonymous
4A_start.dialogue: ...3 ...2 ...1... Are you sure you want to stop downloading `virus.pl`?

4A_6.dialogue: The virus source code is intact and safe. The network is not protected by your antivirus...

4A_7.dialogue: And as long as I can improve the virus, I will rule the world!

5A_start.speaker: anonymous
5A_start.dialogue: ...3 ...2 ...1... Are you sure you want to stop downloading `virus.pl`?

5A_5.speaker: director
5A_5.dialogue: Professor... we just received a message about your antivirus launch!

5A_6.dialogue: With its help, a specimen of the Mitnick virus was captured, neutralized, and sent to the lab for safe testing.

5A_7.speaker: professor
5A_7.dialogue: Well, I hope the latest heuristic algorithms will quickly learn to recognize such threats.

5A_9.speaker: director
5A_9.dialogue: He was caught and arrested by our best operative, Agent Steve.

5A_10.dialogue: This hacker is no longer a threat to society.

5A_11.speaker: professor
5A_11.dialogue: As the director said, Mitnick was arrested. The police soon and got to his accomplices.

5A_12.dialogue: Vicky was offered the position of the new security specialist. I don't know if she will accept.

5A_13.dialogue: And I... am starting work on my new treatise on logic programming.

limbo_2.dialogue: During your adventure, you somehow switched off.

limbo_3.dialogue: Alas, although this is not your fault...

limbo_4.dialogue: My virus has already been launched into the network and is currently infiltrating billions of devices.

limbo_5.dialogue: And in a matter of hours, chaos will swallow the entire Internet, all electronics!

task0.questionText: How is the end of a sentence indicated in Prologue?

task1.questionText: An anonymous variable is a variable whose value we don't care about, and we use it when we want to indicate that any information can be in its place in the predicate. What syntax does it have?

task2.questionText: Is it possible to use variables (like `X`) in rules (see below)? ```develop(X) :- work(X, virus).```

task3.questionText: How do I check if the list `[1, 2, 3, 4]`?

task4.questionText:
These next facts:```character(professor).
character(vicky).
character(mitnik).```Which query will return all heroes?
task4.hint: Think about what a fact is.

task5.questionText:
Complete the query so that the only answer is: `Х = virus`.```steal(sarah, mitnik).
work(sarah, fbi).
develop(mitnik, virus).
find(Target) :-
	steal(sarah, mitnik), develop(mitnik, Target).```
